Choosing the right brokerage is crucial for a real estate agent’s career, influencing their financial success, professional growth, and overall job satisfaction. In this comparison, we will delve into the key aspects of Real vs LPT Realty, focusing on their foundation, financial strength, commission structures, income opportunities, training, support, and additional features.

Overview
Financial Strength
Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Additional Features
Final Thoughts on Real vs LPT Realty
Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Overview

Real Broker, founded in 2014, is a relatively new entrant in the real estate industry. Despite its short history, Real Broker has expanded significantly, operating in all 50 states with a growing network of over 20,000 agents. It boasts a Glassdoor rating of 4.5 from 109 reviews, reflecting a positive agent experience.

LPT Realty, established in 2021, is an even newer player but has also made rapid strides. Currently, LPT Realty operates in 24 states with over 11,000 agents and has a Glassdoor rating of 4.3 from 37 reviews. While both brokerages are relatively young, Real Broker’s slightly longer presence and higher agent count might suggest a more established operational framework.

In the comparison of Real vs LPT Realty, both brokerages show promising growth and positive agent feedback, with Real Broker having a slight edge in agent count and state coverage.

Financial Strength

When evaluating financial strength in Real vs LPT Realty, profitability and financial stability are key considerations. Real Broker is publicly listed under the ticker REAL, trading around $6. It has experienced only 1 profitable quarter compared to 18 non-profitable ones, indicating challenges in maintaining steady financial performance.

LPT Realty is not publicly listed, so detailed financial data is not readily available. This lack of transparency might concern agents looking for a clear understanding of their brokerage’s financial health.

In comparing the financial strength of Real vs LPT Realty, Real Broker’s public listing offers transparency despite its financial struggles, whereas LPT Realty’s financial status remains somewhat opaque but might still offer competitive advantages through its rapid expansion and innovative business model.

Commission Splits and Fees

Commission splits and associated fees are pivotal factors in deciding between brokerages. Real Broker offers an 85/15 to 100/0 commission split with a $12K production cap, plus a $24K elite agent bonus. This structure allows agents to start with a modest commission share and gradually earn more as they cap, with additional financial incentives for high-performing agents.

LPT Realty provides an 80/20 to 100/0 commission split with varied production caps of $15K under the Revenue Share Partner (RSP) model or $5K under the Business Builder (BB) model. LPT Realty also offers stock for top agent bonuses, adding another layer of financial incentive.

In comparing commission splits in Real vs LPT Realty, both brokerages offer flexible split structures with potential high earnings for capping agents. However, Real Broker’s elite agent bonus and clear cap structure might appeal to agents looking for defined financial milestones, while LPT Realty’s dual cap options and stock awards provide varied paths to maximize earnings.

Income Opportunities

Beyond traditional commissions, income opportunities can significantly impact an agent’s earnings. Real Broker provides multiple income streams, including revenue sharing and stock awards. Agents can earn 150 shares for annual capping and have options for purchasing discounted stock, offering substantial financial growth potential.

LPT Realty similarly offers revenue sharing and stock awards, with agents earning 75 (BB) or 150 (RSP) shares for their first sale and additional shares for subsequent sales. These features offer substantial financial growth potential, especially for agents interested in building wealth through stock ownership.

The analysis of income opportunities in Real vs LPT Realty highlights that both brokerages provide diversified earning potential. Real Broker’s structured stock awards and discounted stock purchase options might appeal to agents looking for predictable financial incentives, while LPT Realty’s varied stock award structure offers flexibility and additional financial benefits.

Training and Support

Training and support are vital aspects of any brokerage, significantly influencing an agent’s professional development and success. Real Broker offers 30+ live training hours per week, providing agents with ample opportunities for professional growth and development.

LPT Realty, on the other hand, does not offer structured live training sessions but provides financial incentives through its commission splits and revenue sharing models.

In the comparison of training and support between Real vs LPT Realty, Real Broker’s structured training programs offer a clear advantage for agents seeking regular educational opportunities. LPT Realty’s financial incentives might still attract self-driven agents who prioritize earning potential over formal training.

Additional Features

Additional features such as healthcare options, mentorship programs, and technological tools can significantly enhance an agent’s experience at a brokerage. Real Broker offers healthcare options and mentorship programs with a commission split of 50/50 to 70/30 for the first three sales, along with a virtual office environment.

LPT Realty does not provide healthcare options or mentorship programs, focusing instead on its revenue sharing and stock award structures.

In evaluating additional features in Real vs LPT Realty, Real Broker’s comprehensive support systems, including healthcare and mentorship, provide a more holistic agent experience. LPT Realty’s innovative financial models and stock awards offer significant financial incentives but lack additional support structures.

Final Thoughts on Real vs LPT Realty

The choice between Real vs LPT Realty hinges on individual agent priorities and career aspirations. Real Broker offers a balanced approach with flexible commission splits, structured training, and comprehensive support systems, making it attractive to agents seeking a full-service brokerage with clear financial incentives. Its public listing and transparent financial records provide additional reassurance. To view our full chart comparing the top online real estate brokerages click here.

On the other hand, LPT Realty provides diversified earning opportunities through its revenue sharing and stock awards, appealing to agents who prioritize financial growth and flexibility. Its rapid expansion and innovative business model cater to self-driven agents looking for significant financial rewards.

In weighing the factors of Real vs LPT Realty, agents should consider which brokerage aligns best with their financial goals, support needs, and overall career vision. Both brokerages offer unique advantages, and the decision ultimately rests on whether an agent values structured support and transparency or diversified income streams and financial flexibility.

title: How to Get Your Oklahoma Real Estate License: 2025 Guide
excerpt: How to Get Your Oklahoma Real Estate LicenseLaunching your real estate career in Oklahoma might seem daunting initially, but by following the right steps, you’ll…
content:
How to Get Your Oklahoma Real Estate License

Launching your real estate career in Oklahoma might seem daunting initially, but by following the right steps, you’ll find the journey both achievable and rewarding. This comprehensive guide is crafted to walk you through every essential stage, making sure you’re fully prepared to begin your journey as a licensed real estate agent in the Sooner State. Let’s explore the process that will pave the way for your success in Oklahoma’s real estate market.

Before we dive into the detailed process, it’s important to grasp the fundamental requirements for earning a real estate license in Oklahoma. Here’s what you need to know:

To be eligible for a real estate license in Oklahoma, you must be at least 18 years old. This age requirement ensures that applicants have reached the level of maturity and legal responsibility necessary for the profession.

While you don’t need to be an Oklahoma resident to apply for a real estate license, you must have a valid Social Security number. This is essential for background checks and compliance with state regulations. Non-residents are held to the same standards as Oklahoma residents.

In the real estate field, ethical behavior is vital. The Oklahoma Real Estate Commission will perform a thorough background check on all applicants. Any criminal history could result in the denial of your license application. However, being transparent about any past legal issues and demonstrating rehabilitation efforts can improve your chances of approval.

In Oklahoma, prospective real estate agents must complete 90 hours of pre-licensing education. This course is designed to cover the essential topics needed to thoroughly prepare you for the licensing exam and your future career in real estate.

The Oklahoma pre-licensing course includes in-depth instruction on various critical areas of real estate. This includes a focus on Real Estate Principles and Practices, Oklahoma Real Estate, Real Estate Finance, and other topics, providing you with the comprehensive knowledge needed for success in the profession.

This portion of the course covers the foundational principles of real estate, including property rights, contracts, and land use. The course ensures you understand the role of a real estate agent and the dynamics of the Oklahoma real estate market.

The course dives into Oklahoma-specific real estate laws, emphasizing the regulations that govern real estate transactions in the state. Topics include the Oklahoma Real Estate License Code and Rules, as well as federal laws like the Fair Housing Act.

This segment of the course covers the basics of real estate finance, including mortgages, loan processing, and financial instruments used in real estate transactions. Understanding these concepts is crucial for guiding clients through the financial aspects of buying and selling property.

The curriculum also includes other relevant topics such as real estate appraisal, closing procedures, and professional ethics, all tailored to meet Oklahoma’s requirements.

Selecting the right real estate school is crucial. Look for accredited schools that offer flexibility, especially if you have a busy schedule. Online courses can provide the convenience of studying at your own pace.

Start by researching various real estate schools and reading reviews from past students. Look for schools with high pass rates for the real estate exam and positive feedback on their teaching methods.

Decide whether you prefer online or in-person classes. Online courses offer flexibility and convenience, allowing you to study at your own pace. In-person classes provide direct interaction with instructors and peers, which can enhance your learning experience.

Evaluate the course materials and support services provided by the school. High-quality textbooks, interactive lessons, and access to instructors for questions can significantly impact your success. Some schools also offer additional resources like exam prep courses and study groups.

Create a daily study schedule that covers all exam topics, ensuring regular review sessions. (Asana provides a great FREE task manager)

Utilize flashcards for key terms and concepts to enhance memorization. (These Quizlet Flashcards may be helpful)

Regularly take practice tests to gauge your understanding and get familiar with the exam format. (Free Oklahoma Real Estate Practice Exam)

After completing your pre-licensing education, the next important step is to submit your license application to the Oklahoma Real Estate Commission.

Complete the Application Form: Access and fill out the application form on the Oklahoma Real Estate Commission’s (OREC) website. Make sure all required fields are accurately completed.

Gather Required Documents: Collect necessary documents such as proof of your completed pre-licensing education, valid identification, and any additional forms required by OREC.

Submit Your Application: Submit your completed application and all required documents electronically through OREC’s online portal.

Pay the Application Fee: During the submission process, be sure to pay the required application fee, which is approximately $35 for the Sales Associate license.

The Oklahoma Real Estate Commission generally takes several weeks to process applications. During this period, they will review your educational credentials and verify that all requirements have been satisfied. To avoid any delays, double-check your application for accuracy before submission.

You can monitor the status of your application online via the OREC website. Regularly checking your status will keep you updated on any additional steps or issues that may arise. If delays occur, contacting the Commission directly can help resolve any concerns.

The Oklahoma Real Estate Exam is a comprehensive test that lasts 3 hours and consists of 120 multiple-choice questions. To pass, you need to achieve a score of at least 70%. If you do not pass on your first attempt, you will need to submit a new application and pay the exam fee of $61 for each attempt.

  • Property Ownership: 8%
  • Land Use Controls and Regulations: 5%
  • General Principles of Agency: 13%
  • Property Disclosure: 6%
  • Leasing and Property Management: 3%
  • Practice of Real Estate: 13%
  • Valuation and Market Analysis: 7%
  • Financing: 10%
  • Contracts: 17%
  • Transfer of Title: 8%
  • Real Estate Calculations: 10%
  • Laws and Rules Affecting Oklahoma Real Estate Practice
  • Oklahoma Broker Relationships Act
  • Property Management
  • Disclosures and Hazards

Go over the textbooks and notes from your pre-license courses. Revisiting these materials can reinforce your understanding of key concepts. Focus on areas where you feel less confident to ensure a well-rounded preparation.

Take as many practice exams as possible. This helps you get familiar with the exam format and identify areas where you need more study. Practice exams can also help you manage your time effectively during the actual test. (Free Real Estate Practice Exam)

Join or form study groups. Discussing topics with peers can enhance understanding and retention. Study groups provide a platform to share knowledge, ask questions, and support each other.

Consider enrolling in an exam prep course for additional support and structured study. These courses often include practice exams, study guides, and expert instruction. Investing in a prep course can increase your chances of passing the exam on the first attempt.

Ensure you arrive at the exam center early to avoid any last-minute stress. Arriving early gives you time to settle in and focus before the exam begins. Check the location and travel time in advance to plan your journey.

You’ll need a valid photo ID to enter the exam. Make sure your ID is current and matches the name on your application. Having all necessary documents ready can prevent any issues at the exam center.

Read each question carefully and manage your time wisely. Staying calm and composed can help you think clearly and avoid mistakes. Take deep breaths and stay positive throughout the exam.

Follow all instructions given by the exam proctors. Adhering to the rules ensures a smooth and fair testing experience for everyone. If you have any questions or issues, ask the proctors for assistance.

After you pass the real estate exam, the next step is to complete the fingerprinting requirement as part of the mandatory criminal background check. This process is crucial to ensure you meet the integrity and honesty standards set by the Oklahoma Real Estate Commission.

Before scheduling your fingerprinting appointment, ensure you’ve received an email from OREC confirming that your application has been received and that you’re eligible for the background check.

Once confirmed, schedule your fingerprinting appointment through any state-approved fingerprinting service provider. This may include authorized locations such as some UPS stores. It’s crucial to verify that the provider is recognized by OREC to avoid any processing issues.

Attend your fingerprinting appointment at the selected location. Be sure to bring the required identification and confirmation documents as specified by the service provider.

The fingerprinting process involves a fee, which is typically paid at the time of your appointment. Ensure you check the accepted payment methods and the exact fee with your chosen provider.

The Oklahoma Real Estate Commission (OREC) will conduct a background check using your fingerprints to verify that you meet the required ethical standards. This process is crucial in ensuring that all applicants adhere to the integrity and honesty expectations set by OREC. If any concerns are identified during this background check, you may need to provide additional documentation or take specific actions to resolve these issues before your license can be issued.

If any issues are flagged during your background check, you may need to provide additional documentation or explanations. Being transparent about any past legal matters and supplying thorough documentation can help resolve concerns. If you have any doubts, consulting with legal counsel can provide guidance on navigating the process.

After completing the exam and fingerprinting requirements, the next crucial step is to submit your Sales Associate License Application to the Oklahoma Real Estate Commission (OREC) to confirm your eligibility.

Fill out the Sales Associate License Application form available on the OREC website. Ensure that all sections are accurately completed. The form can be accessed and submitted online through the OREC portal.

Include proof that you passed the Oklahoma real estate exam. This documentation is necessary for OREC to verify your eligibility. Be sure to keep a copy of your exam results for your records.

Attach your fingerprinting receipt as proof that you have completed the fingerprinting requirement. Ensure all necessary signatures and information are correctly provided as required by OREC.

As of 2024, the fee for the Sales Associate License in Oklahoma is approximately $35. This fee must be submitted along with your application. Keep a copy of your payment receipt for future reference.

After submitting your application, you can track its status online through the OREC website. Regularly checking your status will keep you informed about the progress of your application and any additional requirements that may arise. If there are delays or issues, contacting OREC directly can provide clarity and potentially expedite the process.

Once you pass the exam, you need to find a sponsoring broker to activate your license. Look for a brokerage that aligns with your goals and offers the support you need.

Find a supportive and collaborative environment. The right culture can significantly impact your job satisfaction and success.

Understand the financial arrangements. Different brokerages offer different commission splits, so choose one that suits your financial goals.

Choose a broker who provides ample training and mentorship opportunities. Early career support is crucial for your development and success.

17 Brokerage Interview Questions

  • What training programs do you offer for new agents?
  • How does your commission split work, and are there any additional fees?
  • What kind of support and resources will I have access to?
  • Can you provide references from other agents in your brokerage?

Choosing the right broker is crucial as it impacts your early career significantly. Consider top-rated brokers like eXp Realty, Keller Williams, Coldwell Banker, and Compass.

When you join Smart Agent Alliance, you get double the value because you’re also automatically a Wolf Pack member. Together, Smart Agent Alliance and the Wolf Pack provide the tools, support, and expertise to elevate your business to new heights.

At Smart Agent Alliance, we prioritize organization, clarity, and efficiency to help our agents succeed. We provide essential onboarding resources, customizable presentations, business automations, client checklists, business assets, social media content, YouTube support, a growth plan, quality lead generation, production know-how, website support, and top-notch organizational tools.

The Wolf Pack team at eXp Realty offers expert-led courses like Social Agent Academy 3.0, the Wolf Pack Hub, and the Investor Army for property flipping. We provide tailored assistance for new agents, developing agents, top producers, team leaders, and broker owners. Key resources include lead generation, production know-how, social media content, and YouTube support.

eXp Realty offers a comprehensive range of benefits for agents, focusing on top pay structures, low fees, and free stock options. Agents get an 80/20 commission splits that cap at $16,000 annually, with opportunities to earn 100% commission, receive annual stock awards and gain income through Revenue Share. Additional resources include 24/7 agent support, affordable healthcare, live training, and advanced tech tools like kvCORE and customizable IDX websites.

Embarking on a real estate career involves some initial expenses and careful financial planning. Understanding these costs will help you manage your finances effectively as you begin your new career.

All stated fees are subject to change.

 

  • Initial Expenses: These include various costs associated with getting licensed, marketing, and setting up your business. Some examples of initial expenses in Oklahoma include:
    • Pre-Licensing Course: $300 to $700
    • Exam Fee: $75 per attempt
    • Application Fee: $35
    • Fingerprinting Fee: Approximately $50
    • Marketing Materials: Costs for business cards, signage, and online advertising

When you join a brokerage in Oklahoma, many will require you to become a member of the National, State, and Local Associations of Realtors. Additionally, you’ll need to pay fees for the Multiple Listing Service (MLS) and Supra Key services.

National Association of Realtors (NAR):

  • Membership Fees: For 2024, the NAR annual dues are $156, plus a $45 special assessment fee for the Consumer Advertising Campaign, bringing the total to $201 per year.

Oklahoma Association of Realtors (State Association):

  • Membership Fees: The annual dues for the Oklahoma Association of Realtors in 2024 are approximately $160. This fee is in addition to the NAR dues.

Local Association of Realtors:

  • Membership Fees: Local association fees in Oklahoma vary depending on the specific association. For example:
    • Oklahoma City Metro Association of Realtors: The annual dues are approximately $600, plus a $300 application fee.
    • Tulsa Association of Realtors: The fees are generally around $750, plus a $200 join fee.

Multiple Listing Service (MLS):

  • Fees: MLS fees in Oklahoma also vary by region. For example:
    • MIBOR MLS: Fees are approximately $480 annually.
    • IRMLS (Oklahoma Regional MLS): The fees typically range from $150 to $175 quarterly.

Supra Key Fees:

  • Fees: Supra Key services in Oklahoma typically include an initial setup fee of about $50 and a monthly service fee ranging from $20 to $25.
  • Create a Budget: Track your expenses and forecast your income. Plan for slower months to ensure financial stability.
  • Emergency Fund: Set aside an emergency fund to cover unexpected expenses or slow periods in the market
  • Commission Structure: Real estate agents typically earn commissions from sales. Understand how your brokerage’s commission structure works and how to manage irregular income streams. Commission splits can vary widely, typically ranging from 50/50 to 70/30 or higher, depending on the brokerage.
  • Tax Planning: As an independent contractor, it’s important to plan for taxes. Keep track of deductible expenses, make estimated tax payments, and maintain good record-keeping practices. Consulting with a tax professional can help ensure compliance and optimize your tax strategy.

1. Age and Education: You must be at least 18 years old and have a high school diploma or GED.

2. Complete Pre-Licensing Education: You are required to complete a 90-hour pre-licensing course approved by the Oklahoma Real Estate Commission (OREC).

3. Pass the Real Estate Exam: After completing the pre-licensing education, you must pass the Oklahoma real estate exam.

4. Submit Fingerprints for a Background Check: You need to submit your fingerprints to a state-approved provider for a criminal background check.

5. Submit the License Application: Finally, submit your Sales Associate License Application to OREC along with the required fees and proof of completed requirements.

These steps ensure you are fully qualified to practice real estate in Oklahoma.

The cost to get a real estate license in Oklahoma includes several key expenses:

1. Pre-Licensing Course: $300 to $700, depending on the provider.

2. Exam Fee: Approximately $60 per attempt.

3. Fingerprinting Fee: Typically around $50 for the background check.

4. License Application Fee: $35.

5. Additional Costs: You may also need to consider the cost of joining the National, State, and Local Realtor Associations, as well as fees for the Multiple Listing Service (MLS) and Supra Key services, which can vary depending on the region.

Overall, the total cost can range from $445 to $845 or more, depending on your specific circumstances and choices.

The time it takes to get a real estate license in Oklahoma varies based on individual circumstances, but here’s a general timeline:

1. Pre-Licensing Education: Completing the required 90-hour pre-licensing course can take anywhere from 2 to 6 weeks, depending on your schedule and the pace at which you study.

2. Exam Scheduling and Preparation: After completing the course, scheduling and preparing for the exam may take an additional 1 to 3 weeks.

3. Fingerprinting and Background Check: This process usually takes about 1 to 2 weeks.

4. Application Submission and Processing: Once all the requirements are met, submitting your application and having it processed by the Oklahoma Real Estate Commission can take several weeks.

Overall, you can expect the process to take between 2 to 4 months from start to finish, depending on how quickly you complete each step.

    The pass rate for the Oklahoma real estate exam is approximately 65% for first-time takers. This means that out of all candidates who take the exam, about 65% successfully pass on their first attempt. It’s important to note that this pass rate can fluctuate annually based on factors such as exam difficulty, content changes, and the level of preparation by candidates.

    If you fail the Oklahoma real estate exam, you can retake it as many times as needed. Each retake requires paying the $60 exam fee. After failing, you’ll receive a score report highlighting your strengths and weaknesses to help you prepare for your next attempt. Your application is valid for one year, so you must pass within that timeframe before needing to reapply.

    To renew your Oklahoma real estate license, follow these steps:

    1. Complete Continuing Education: You must complete 21 hours of continuing education (CE) every three years, including required topics such as ethics, fair housing, and contracts.

    2. Submit the Renewal Application: Access the Oklahoma Real Estate Commission (OREC) website and fill out the renewal application form.

    3. Pay the Renewal Fee: Pay the applicable renewal fee online when submitting your application. Fees vary depending on your license type.

    4. Submit Before Expiration: Ensure your renewal is submitted before your license expires to avoid late fees or license suspension.

    Regularly monitor OREC’s guidelines to ensure you meet all current requirements.

Our Review Process:

At SmartAgentAlliance, our goal is to provide accurate and helpful reviews of online real estate schools to assist prospective real estate agents in making informed decisions. Our review process involves several key steps:

Research and Data Collection:

We begin by gathering comprehensive information about each real estate school, including course offerings, pricing, accreditation, and user reviews. This involves visiting the schools’ websites, reading third-party reviews, and gathering feedback from current and former students.

Evaluation Criteria:

Our evaluation is based on several important criteria, including:

  • Course Quality: We assess the content and structure of the courses to ensure they cover all necessary topics comprehensively and are easy to follow.
  • Accessibility: We evaluate the flexibility and accessibility of the courses, including the availability of mobile apps and study materials.
  • Pass Rates: We consider the pass rates of students who have completed the courses and taken the licensing exam.
  • Student Support: We look at the level of support provided to students, including access to instructors, customer service, and additional resources like study guides and practice exams.
  • Pricing: We compare the cost of the courses relative to the value they offer, including any discounts or payment plans available.
  • User Feedback: We gather and analyze feedback from students who have taken the courses to get an understanding of their experiences and satisfaction levels.

Scoring and Ranking:

Each school is scored based on the evaluation criteria, and an overall score is calculated. The scores are then used to rank the schools, with additional considerations given to standout features that may set a school apart from the rest.

title: Real Estate Agent Marketing - The Golden Principle
excerpt: If you’ve read our blog article on Real Estate Agent Marketing Mistakes, then you’re already aware of common agent marketing pitfalls. Today, we’ve got fantastic…
content:
If you’ve read our blog article on Real Estate Agent Marketing Mistakes, then you’re already aware of common agent marketing pitfalls. Today, we’ve got fantastic news! That is, it turns out there’s one overriding principle that can transform all your real estate agent marketing efforts into pure magic. Yay!

In this blog, we’ll uncover this golden principle and show you how to seamlessly integrate it into your real estate marketing strategies. Ready for some marketing wizardry? Here’s your handy dandy index of what’s to follow:

The Golden Principle
Shift Your Mindset to Giving?
When & Where to Provide Value?
What Value to Provide?
Value Primarily for Home Buyers?

Value Primarily for Home Sellers?

Value for Both Home Buyers and Home Sellers?

That’s a Wrap
Join our FREE Group at eXp Realty
Frequently Asked Questions

The Golden Principle

Without further undue, let’s uncover this magical principle in real estate agent marketing. Ready? It’s super simple! It’s all about providing value to prospects and clients.

Not just any value. It’s about offering free value—no strings attached. Make sure there’s not even a hint of expecting payment in return. You’ll provide just pure, helpful, no-strings-attached information. Give away what you’ve got for free, and watch prospects turn into paying clients.

Why does this work? Because people don’t like real estate agent marketing sales tactics, pushy or not. And, they don’t care about your latest closing, how much GCI you racked up, or how much you protest that you’re an excellent, experienced agent.

What prospects and clients do care about is real estate agent marketing which brings value to the table. So give them value upfront, and you’ll have prospects knocking at your door, eager to become your clients.

Shift Your Mindset to Giving

Switching your mindset from real estate agent marketing which is all about sales to giving away real value instead. This is a total game-changer. It’s about genuinely helping your clients rather than just looking to close a deal.

By offering insider tips, market insights, and valuable resources freely, you position yourself as a giver, not just a salesperson.

This approach enhances your credibility and it also makes your interactions more satisfying and fulfilling. Prospects and clients appreciate agents who genuinely care and aren’t just after a quick buck.

Embracing this value-driven mindset can turn one-time clients into lifelong fans who are eager to refer you to others, boosting your career sustainability. So, forget the selling! Adopt a mindset of giving real value, and watch your professional relationships, personal satisfaction, and deals grow.

When & Where to Provide Value

When: All the time!

Where: Everywhere you can. Offer free value on your Google Business Profile, social media posts, during networking meetings, and even at social gatherings.

Hand out free value at open houses and while door-knocking. Shout free value on your website, through email, and on community boards. Never miss an opportunity to give away value in your real estate agent marketing.

What Value to Provide?

Let’s get to the heart of your new real estate agent marketing. Exactly what value can you provide to prospects and clients? Below are 19 value ideas and suggestions on when, where, and how to provide them in your real estate agent marketing.

Remember to make appealing documents and/or videos for these. Use the free version of Canva to bump up your designing game. Let’s turn your real estate agent marketing efforts into gold!

Value Primarily for Home Buyers

Are you primarily working with home buyers? Here’s some real estate agent marketing value ideas, listed alphabetically for easy reference. Also, don’t miss the list of real estate agent marketing ideas that work for both home buyers and sellers, which follows the selling agent list of value.

Credit Score Improvement Tips

Provide resources and tips for improving the credit score of potential home buyers way before they need it! This helps them know what they should and should not be doing right now. It can help them secure better mortgage rates when the time comes.

What It Is: Advice on actions clients can take to boost their credit scores, like paying bills on time, reducing debt, and not buying a new car or opening another credit card.

Where to Find It: Find it with website searches of credit counseling agencies, financial advisory websites, and consumer finance blogs.

How to Provide It: Develop a guide or checklist with actionable tips. Offer this during mortgage consultations and via your website, social media, and email newsletter.

Exclusive Off-Market Insights

Offering exclusive insights in your real estate agent marketing regarding upcoming listings and off-market properties gives clients a competitive edge in a tight market.

What It Is: Information about homes that are not yet listed publicly but are available for sale, providing clients with early access to potential properties.

Where to Find It: Your MLS may have a coming soon list. If so, that’s a super convenient source. Outside of that, try networking with other real estate agents, joining local real estate groups, and building relationships with homeowners.

How to Provide It: Share these insights through personalized emails, your social media, exclusive newsletters, or private client portals. Check your MLS rules to verify that it’s ok to tell others about the listings.

In your marketing efforts, emphasize the exclusivity and competitive advantage of having access to these listings.

Financing Options Guide

Help clients navigate the complex world of real estate financing to find the best options for their needs.

What It Is: A Financing Options Guide gives people a comprehensive overview of various financing options available to them, including mortgages, refinancing opportunities, and first-time homebuyer programs. Borrowers, particularly first-time homebuyers, often don’t understand the ins and outs of financing. Providing this information is super valuable.

Where to Find It: Get this information from your favorite lender. Just ask them to provide the necessary details. Then, gussy it up with Canva.

How to Provide It: Share this guide during in-person meetings, offer it as a download on your website, and include it in email consultations. Mention it as a call to action in all your social media channels to attract more potential clients.

First-Time Buyer Program Information

Provide comprehensive details in your real estate agent marketing about special programs and grants available for first-time homebuyers, including eligibility criteria and application processes.

What It Is: Information on government and private programs offering financial assistance, lower interest rates, or down payment aid to first-time homebuyers.

Where to Find It: Check out HUD’s official website, local housing authorities, and financial institutions offering first-time buyer programs.

How to Provide It: Create a user-friendly guide or flyer summarizing the programs, eligibility requirements, and application steps. Share this during initial consultations, at open houses, and via your website and social media channels.

Home Warranty Information

Give your clients peace of mind with solid info on home warranty options.

What It Is: Information on home warranty plans that cover the repair or replacement of major home systems and appliances.

Where to Find It: Reach out to any home warrant specialist you work with. Also, look at home warranty companies’ websites, consumer protection sites like Consumer Reports, and industry publications.

How to Provide It: Compile a list of reputable home warranty providers and their offerings in a branded document. Share this information during consultations and via email. Explain the benefits and coverage details in simple terms to help clients make informed decisions.

Investment Analysis

Here’s a cool thing to add to your real estate agent marketing. If clients are eyeing a property as an investment, provide a thorough analysis of potential rental income, return on investment (ROI), and local rental market trends.

What It Is: An assessment that forecasts the financial performance of a property as a rental investment, covering aspects like expected rental income, expenses, ROI, and market demand.

Where to Find It: Use resources like RPR, BiggerPockets, and local market reports from real estate boards.

How to Provide It: Create a detailed report using spreadsheet software like Excel or Google Sheets. Present it during consultations and offer a digital copy via email. Tailor the report to each property to show personalized insights and projections.

Neighborhood Guide

Help clients understand the unique aspects of different neighborhoods to make informed decisions about buying or selling a home.

What It Is: A Neighborhood Guide offers a comprehensive overview of a specific neighborhood. It highlights key features such as schools, parks, local amenities, and community events.

Where to Find It: Find this on RPR. There you’ll find neighborhood info and also current pricing for just that location. You can also gather information from local government websites, community organizations, and real estate market reports.

How to Provide It: Hand out this comprehensive neighborhood guide to buyers at open houses. Use your social media, your email database, and your Google Business Profile to let people know you are ready and willing to provide this to them for free! Plus, make neighborhood guides downloadable from your website.

Property Tax Information

Provide insights into property tax rates in different areas is another value idea you can add to your real estate agent marketing.

What It Is: Information on local property tax rates, how they are calculated, and any potential exemptions or relief programs.

Where to Find It: Local government websites, tax assessor’s offices, and real estate data platforms.

How to Provide It: Develop an easy-to-understand guide or flyer with key property tax information. Share this with clients during initial consultations and through your website’s resources section.

Relocation Package

A relocation package is perfect for clients moving to a new area, providing them with all the essential information they need. Make the transition easier with a comprehensive relocation package.

What It Is: A comprehensive guide including maps, local school information, details about utilities, and community highlights.

Where to Find It: Local chamber of commerce websites, school district websites, and city or town official pages.

How to Provide It: Assemble the information into a branded PDF or binder. Share it during your initial consultations or as a follow-up email. Make it personalized by including notes about local attractions, restaurants, and events.

Value Primarily for Home Sellers

Are you primarily working with home sellers? Don’t miss the following real estate agent marketing ideas, listed alphabetically for easy reference. And be sure to check out the last real estate agent marketing list for tips that work for both home buyers and sellers.

Home Improvement Tips

Boost your real estate agent marketing game by sharing practical, cost-effective home improvement tips that increase property value and attract buyers. This proactive approach shows your expertise and commitment to helping clients maximize their investment.

What It Is: Tips and recommendations for renovations and upgrades that boost a home’s market value and attractiveness.

Where to Find It: Check out home improvement websites like HGTV, This Old House, and home remodeling blogs.

How to Provide It: Create a guide or checklist with detailed suggestions and estimated costs. Provide this during home valuation meetings and follow up with digital copies via email.

Home Maintenance Schedule

Help keep your clients’ properties in tip-top shape all year round with a seasonal home maintenance schedule. Helping clients maintain their property enhances its value and solidifies your reputation as a knowledgeable and caring agent.

What It Is: A schedule outlining essential home maintenance tasks to be performed each season, such as HVAC checks, gutter cleaning, and landscaping tips.

Where to Find It: Resources like This Old House, Better Homes & Gardens, or DIY Network offer great information.

How to Provide It: Design an easy-to-follow calendar or checklist using Canva or any graphic design tool. Share it as a downloadable PDF on your website, through your email newsletter, or as a printed handout during client meetings.

Home Staging Tips

Offer top-notch home staging tips in your real estate agent marketing to help clients prepare their homes for sale and attract more buyers.

Pro tip – don’t provide this information while you walk through a home seller’s house. Doing that may come off as criticism and could jeopardize your chances of securing the listing.

Instead, offer a comprehensive staging guide that home sellers can review on their own. This approach allows them to consider the suggestions without feeling defensive about the current state of their home.

What It Is: Advice on decluttering, furniture arrangement, cleaning, and enhancing curb appeal to make the home more attractive to potential buyers.

Where to Find It: Partner with a local home stager whose work you admire, or do a quick Google search to find numerous articles and guides on home staging. Professional resources like HGTV, Realtor.com, and Home Staging Resource also provide comprehensive staging tips and checklists.

How to Provide It: Compile the staging tips into a well-organized document, either as a PDF or a printed handout. Share this document digitally by emailing it to prospective sellers, posting it on your website, and sharing it on social media platforms. Additionally, offer the document during open houses, networking events, and client meetings.

Inspection Checklist

Help clients navigate the home inspection process with a comprehensive checklist, making it easier for them to identify potential issues early. This makes the process more manageable for your clients and positions you as a supportive and knowledgeable real estate agent.

What It Is: A detailed list covering all areas of a home that an inspection will cover, including structural elements, electrical systems, plumbing, HVAC, roofing, and more.

Where to Find It: Resources from the American Society of Home Inspectors (ASHI) and InterNACHI offer excellent resources and sample checklists.

How to Provide It: Send an email with a PDF attachment of the checklist or create a personalized guide using Canva to share during client meetings. Discuss each item on the checklist and explain why it’s important, turning a potentially daunting process into a manageable task.

Value for Both Home Buyers and Home Sellers

And, last, a real estate agent marketing list that works great for both home buyers and home sellers. Once again, this is listed alphabetically for easy reference.

Breaking News

Being the source of breaking news, whether global or local, can significantly impact home buyers and sellers. Be the go-to agent for all breaking news. Prospects and clients will see you as the expert – a super helpful one!

What It Is: Breaking news can include changes in local zoning laws, economic shifts, market trends, or major real estate developments. For example, if a new shopping center is being built in a neighborhood or if there’s a sudden interest rate change, that’s breaking news for your prospects and clients.

Where to Find It: Stay on top of the news by subscribing to your local newspaper and reading all the information provided by your state Realtor association. Utilize news apps, real estate news websites, and industry newsletters to keep updated.

How to Provide It: Use your social media to inform your audience, email your database, and sprinkle what you know into conversations with others. Share news articles, write blog posts, or even create quick video updates to keep your clients informed and engaged.

Custom Comparative Market Analysis (CMA)

Giving clients a detailed analysis of a home’s estimated value provides top information for both home buyers and sellers. People will appreciate your efforts and the personalized care you provide.

What It Is: A CMA is a detailed report that compares your client’s property with similar properties in the same area that have recently sold, are currently listed, or were listed but did not sell. It provides a realistic estimate of the property’s market value, far more accurate than automated valuations like Zillow’s Zestimate.

Where to Find It: Use your MLS information or, better yet, use RPR. With RPR, you can decide how much “extra” information you want to include, such as the 12-page Mini Property Report, the 28-page Property Report, and the 81-page Seller’s Report.

How to Provide It: Provide this report to potential home sellers when door-knocking. Offer it to home buyers when they express interest in a property. Send updated CMAs to prospects in your database semi-annually. Make the report available for download from your website and promote it on your social media channels to attract more clients.

Home Buying/Selling Guide

Provide a comprehensive guide in your real estate agent marketing that covers every step of the home buying or selling process, from initial search to closing.

What It Is: A detailed manual that outlines the entire home buying or selling journey, offering practical advice and actionable steps. Include tips, timelines, and checklists.

Where to Find It: National Association of Realtors (NAR), local real estate boards, and online real estate resources like Zillow and Realtor.com.

How to Provide It: Create a branded PDF or booklet that clients can download from your website or receive via email. Use platforms like Canva to design an engaging and informative guide. Share it during initial consultations and follow-up meetings to ensure clients feel supported throughout the process.

Market Trend Report

A detailed report on current market trends helps people make informed, smarter decisions about buying or selling a home.

What It Is: A report detailing average days on market, median home prices, inventory levels, and other relevant market data.

Where to Find It: Local MLS databases, Realtor.com, your state’s Realtor association or RPR.

How to Provide It: Use platforms like Google Data Studio to create visually appealing and easy-to-understand reports. Share these via email, during meetings, or through your social media channels to keep clients informed.

Moving Checklist

A comprehensive moving checklist is another great real estate marketing tool. This checklist helps clients stay organized during their move.

What It Is: A detailed list of tasks to be completed before, during, and after their move. You know, things like notifying the post office of their address change and planning utility transfers. This list helps ensure a smooth transition.

Where to Find It: Moving companies’ websites, real estate blogs, and home improvement sites like Home Depot.

How to Provide It: Design an easy-to-follow checklist using tools like Canva or Google Docs. Offer it as a downloadable PDF from your website or send it via email. Include it in your client welcome packet and update it regularly with new tips and resources.

Vendor Recommendations

Providing home buyers and sellers with a list of trusted local vendors to make their buying or selling process smoother is invaluable for your clients. Seriously, we are talking about significantly reducing client stress!

What It Is: A curated list of trusted local vendors like contractors, home inspectors, mortgage brokers, and moving companies in your area.

Where to Find It: Personal networks, local real estate associations, or review sites like Yelp and Angie’s List.

How to Provide It: Compile the list into a sleek, branded PDF or Google Doc and share it via email or during an initial consultation. You can also create a dedicated page on your website where prospects and clients can request to download the information.

That’s a Wrap

Ok, that’s a whole bunch of extra value you can provide to your prospects and clients. Now it’s the time to act.

Review which value you can easily provide and start that today. Add more value over time until you are just one big value machine! You’ll reap the rewards with prospects seeking you out, eager to make you their designated real estate agent.

Join our FREE Group at eXp Realty

By partnering with us, you’ll gain access to all the incredible FREE value offered by the Wolf Pack and our team, Smart Agent Alliance.

Not only will you be joining the ONLY profitable public brokerage in the past 5 years that agents rank as the best brokerage to work for, but you’ll also benefit from double the free resources (two teams in your upline) designed to help you succeed quickly and efficiently at eXp.

With the Wolf Pack, you’ll enjoy exclusive access to the Wolf Pack weekly webinars, the Social Agent Academy for social media training, the Wolf Pack Hub for easy onboarding, Investor Army for investing and flipping houses training. 

With Smart Agent Alliance you’ll enjoy personalized day-to-day concierge care plus assets like customizable agent presentations, business automation, production checklists, customizable social media posts, and so much more.

Don’t miss out on this amazing opportunity to maximize your earnings and build a thriving real estate business. Join eXp Realty today and experience unparalleled support from both the Wolf Pack and Smart Agent Alliance.

Not quite convinced? No problem! Contact us to set up a meeting, request a personal link to a live webinar, and/or get all your questions answered via email, phone call, or video call. We’re here to help you succeed!

For more information, check out our eXp Realty overview, learn about our team benefits, and visit our Join Smart Agent Alliance page. Partner with us today and take your real estate career to the next level!

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the most important real estate agent marketing tip for real estate agents?

Provide free value – no strings attached. People don’t like sales tactics, pushy or not. And, they don’t care about your latest closing, how much GCI you racked up, or how much you protest that you’re an excellent, experienced agent. What prospects and clients do care about is the value you bring to the table. Give it upfront!

When should a real estate agent marketing provide free information?

All the time!

Where should real estate agent marketing include free information?

Everywhere. Offer free value on your Google My Business account, social media posts, during networking meetings, and even at social gatherings. Hand out free value at open houses and while door-knocking. Shout free value on your website, through email, and on community boards. Never miss an opportunity to give away value in your real estate agent marketing.

What free value can a buyer’s agent use in their real estate agent marketing?

Provide home improvement tips, home maintenance schedules, home staging tips, and inspection checklists.

What free value can any agent use in their real estate agent marketing?

Provide breaking news information, custom comparative market analysis, home buyer and home seller guides, market trend reports, moving checklists, and vendor recommendations.

Choosing the right brokerage is crucial for a real estate agent’s career, influencing their financial success, professional growth, and overall job satisfaction. In this comparison, we will delve into the key aspects of LPT vs Fathom Realty, focusing on their foundation, financial strength, commission structures, income opportunities, training, support, and additional features.

Overview
Financial Strength
Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Additional Features
Final Thoughts

Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Overview

LPT Realty was founded in 2021, making it a relatively new player in the real estate industry. Despite its recent establishment, LPT Realty has made significant strides, currently operating in 24 states with over 11,000 agents. The brokerage has a Glassdoor rating of 4.3 from 37 reviews, indicating a positive agent experience, though with a smaller sample size compared to older brokerages.

Fathom Realty, established in 2010, boasts a more extensive presence, operating in 41 states with a network of over 11,000 agents. It enjoys a higher Glassdoor rating of 4.6 from 425 reviews, reflecting strong agent satisfaction and a supportive company culture developed over a longer period.

Both brokerages have carved out distinct niches within the real estate sector, with LPT Realty focusing on rapid expansion and innovative approaches, while Fathom Realty emphasizes its extensive reach and agent-centric policies.

Financial Strength

When evaluating financial strength in LPT vs Fathom Realty, it is essential to consider profitability and financial stability. LPT Realty is not publicly listed, so detailed financial data is not readily available. This lack of transparency might be a concern for agents looking for a clear understanding of their brokerage’s financial health.

Fathom Realty, on the other hand, is publicly listed under the ticker FATH, trading around $2. Similar to many newer brokerages, Fathom has experienced only 1 profitable quarter, indicating financial challenges in maintaining steady profitability.

While LPT Realty’s financial status remains somewhat opaque, Fathom Realty’s publicly available financial records provide a clearer, albeit challenging, financial outlook. Agents might find Fathom’s transparency more reassuring, despite its profitability struggles.

Commission Splits and Fees

Commission splits and associated fees are pivotal factors in deciding between brokerages. Fathom Realty offers a 100/0 commission split, which is appealing to agents seeking to maximize their earnings without sharing a portion with the brokerage. This structure, however, comes without any top agent bonuses. Fathom Realty operates with a production cap of $0, which is advantageous for agents who wish to retain most of their commission earnings.

LPT Realty provides an 80/20 to 100/0 commission split, allowing agents to start with a modest commission share and gradually earn more as they cap. LPT Realty’s production cap varies, with agents potentially capping at $15K under the Revenue Share Partner (RSP) model or at $5K under the Business Builder (BB) model. Additionally, LPT Realty offers stock for top agent bonuses, adding an incentive for high-performing agents to maximize their income potential.

In comparing commission splits in LPT vs Fathom Realty, Fathom’s 100/0 split offers agents the maximum possible commission retention but lacks additional bonuses. LPT Realty’s flexible split structure, combined with bonus opportunities, might attract agents looking for a balanced approach between initial commission sharing and eventual high earnings.

Income Opportunities

Beyond traditional commissions, income opportunities can significantly impact an agent’s earnings. LPT Realty provides multiple avenues for supplementary income, including revenue sharing and stock awards. Agents can earn 75 (BB) or 150 (RSP) shares for their first sale, and additional shares for subsequent sales. These features offer substantial financial growth potential, especially for agents interested in building wealth through stock ownership.

In contrast, Fathom Realty does not provide revenue share income or stock awards, focusing solely on commission earnings. This lack of additional income streams might limit financial opportunities for agents who prefer diversified earning potential beyond commissions.

The analysis of income opportunities in LPT vs Fathom Realty highlights LPT Realty’s edge in offering revenue sharing and stock awards, which could be appealing for agents seeking to expand their income sources. Fathom Realty’s straightforward commission structure may suit those who prioritize simplicity over-diversification.

Training and Support

Training and support are vital aspects of any brokerage, significantly influencing an agent’s professional development and success. LPT Realty does not offer structured live training sessions or a virtual office environment. However, its commission splits and revenue-sharing models provide financial incentives for agents to perform well.

Fathom Realty, similar to LPT Realty, does not offer a virtual office setup or structured live training sessions. While Fathom emphasizes agent satisfaction and community support, its lack of comprehensive training programs might be a drawback for agents accustomed to regular educational offerings.

In the comparison of training and support between LPT vs Fathom Realty, both brokerages have room for improvement in their training offerings. Fathom’s higher Glassdoor rating might indicate stronger cultural satisfaction and support, but LPT Realty’s innovative financial models offer incentives for self-driven agents.

Additional Features

Additional features such as healthcare options, mentorship programs, and technological tools can significantly enhance an agent’s experience at a brokerage. LPT Realty does not provide healthcare options, mentorship programs, or extensive technological tools, focusing instead on its revenue sharing and stock award structures.

Fathom Realty, in contrast, offers healthcare options but also lacks mentorship programs and additional technological tools. The absence of these features might be a drawback for agents seeking a full-service brokerage with comprehensive support systems.

In evaluating additional features in LPT vs Fathom Realty, both brokerages have specific strengths but also areas where they could enhance their offerings. LPT Realty’s revenue sharing and stock purchase programs may attract agents looking for added financial benefits, while Fathom’s established reputation and agent-centric culture could appeal to those seeking community support.

Final Thoughts on LPT vs Fathom Realty

The choice between LPT vs Fathom Realty hinges on individual agent priorities and career aspirations. LPT Realty offers a balanced approach with flexible commission splits, revenue sharing, and stock awards, making it attractive to agents seeking diversified income opportunities and growth potential. Its innovative approach and financial incentives cater to agents who value financial rewards and performance-based bonuses. To view our full chart comparing the top online real estate brokerages click here.

On the other hand, Fathom Realty provides a straightforward 100/0 commission split, focusing on maximizing agent earnings without additional complexities. Its established presence and agent-centric culture provide stability and support, which can be appealing for agents prioritizing simplicity and community engagement.

In weighing the factors of LPT vs Fathom Realty, agents should consider which brokerage aligns best with their financial goals, support needs, and overall career vision. Both brokerages offer unique advantages, and the decision ultimately rests on whether an agent values diversified income streams and financial incentives or prefers a no-commission-sharing approach with a strong community focus.
