title: Revenue Share Compared Showdown: eXp, LPT, Real, Fathom, & KW
excerpt: Key Points 7-tier models generate 400% more agents vs 5-tier models. Revenue share can be passive and inherited. Most brokerages require recruits to unlock tiers.…
content:
Key Points

  • 7-tier models generate 400% more agents vs 5-tier models.
  • Revenue share can be passive and inherited.
  • Most brokerages require recruits to unlock tiers.
  • eXp has no production or fee requirements to earn rev share.
  • Spreadsheet shows actual income comparison, not just marketing hype.

Let’s cut to it – if you’ve been researching real estate revenue share models, you’ve probably already been misled. Not by accident. Not because it’s complicated. But because a whole bunch of YouTubers are out here slinging “facts” that aged worse than expired milk.

Some of them mean well, but never updated their info after the last big brokerage shift. Others? They cherry-pick numbers to make their team look like a six-figure fairy tale, conveniently skipping over the fine print. And somehow, every revenue share video ends with a link to book a call… shocking.

So if you’re wondering “how does revenue share work?” or trying to figure out if eXp revenue share is better than Real’s, or if KW’s “profit share” is even in the same sport, good news, we actually ran the numbers. Real math. Not vibes.

This post strips out the sales fluff and makes every model easy to compare – apples to apples, not apples to ad copy. We’ll show you who pays what, how many tiers each model includes, which brokerages have sneaky rules buried in the footnotes, and how much you could actually earn, not just what someone promised in a webinar pitch.

Here’s your handy-dandy index:

What Is Revenue Sharing? (And Why Agents Should Actually Care)
Why Revenue Share Income Is a Power Move for Agents
How Brokerages Benefit from Revenue Share Models (Hint: They’re Not Altruists)
The Big Names in Revenue Sharing: Who’s In This Breakdown?
Comparing Revenue Sharing Tiers: 7 Tiers vs 5 Tiers = Big Money Gap
Comparing What Brokerages Pay at Each Tier

Let’s break that down with a real example:
Extra Revenue Share: What Happens When There’s Money… But No One to Pay
Differences Too Uncertain to Calculate (But Too Important to Ignore)
Caution: LPT & Fathom Revenue Share Numbers May Be Inflated
Potential Revenue Share Earnings Comparison: The Only Math That Matters

What Is Revenue Sharing? (And Why Agents Should Actually Care)

If the phrase “revenue share” sounds like one of those corporate buzzwords designed to make bad compensation sound better, buckle up. Revenue sharing in real estate is actually where things get interesting, especially if you’ve ever recommended your brokerage to another agent.

Here’s the revenue share definition: it’s a model where brokerages pay agents a cut of the company’s commission revenue when they refer new agents. Not profit-revenue. That’s before the expenses, marketing costs, or whatever your broker’s dog’s spa bill is this month.

And the upside? Massive. For example, eXp Realty revenue share paid agents over $200 million in 2024 alone. Some agents earn passive income topping seven figures a year. Even if you’re not planning to build a massive downline, ignoring what revenue sharing means is like ignoring compound interest. It’s a regret that shows up on every agent’s “wish I started sooner” list.

Why Revenue Share Income Is a Power Move for Agents

Let’s talk retirement plans – for people who don’t trust the stock market and don’t want to sell houses until their knees give out at an open house.

Revenue share income is one of the only paths in real estate that can keep paying you after you stop working. Most revenue share models allow income to continue into retirement (and even after death) as long as you meet a few basic requirements. Spoiler: You won’t find that perk in your commission check.

It’s not just money while you sleep. It’s income you can will to your family. And while brokerages all have slightly different rules (some easy to find, most buried like a secret menu item), the concept is the same – build it right, and this becomes your exit plan from real estate hustle culture.

How Brokerages Benefit from Revenue Share Models (Hint: They’re Not Altruists)

If you thought revenue-sharing companies created these models out of the kindness of their hearts… yeah, no.

Here’s how the game really works: brokerages like eXp, LPT, Real, and Fathom figured out they could outsource agent recruiting to, well, agents. No more bloated ad budgets or ineffective recruiters. Instead, you bring people in, and they toss a slice of their revenue your way. Everyone wins – if agents are producing.

More importantly, revenue share aligns incentives. Recruiters don’t earn unless their recruits are closing deals. So, ideally, they actually help new agents get started. That’s the pitch. Whether it plays out that way? Depends entirely on the people and the brokerage culture. At eXp, for instance, strong revenue share support teams like Smart Agent Alliance make it more than just lip service.

What You Should Actually Care About in a Revenue Share Model

Not all revenue share models are created equal – and no, your friend’s “I made $300 my first year!” testimonial doesn’t count as a reliable metric.

Here’s what you really need to look at:

Income Potential

Each revenue-sharing company has its own puzzle of payout tiers, unlock requirements, and an available revenue share income pool from which to pay recruiting agents. Some brokerages give you a slice of the pie across seven layers of your downline. Others cut you off at five.

Brokerage Sustainability: Because Your Downline Won’t Follow You Twice

Here’s the part most agents miss when chasing revenue share dreams: if your brokerage tanks, so does your passive income.

Building a downline isn’t easy – you invest time, training, and trust. But if your brokerage changes the rules, slaps on new fees, or just plain folds, you’re stuck. And no, most of your agents won’t follow you to the next big thing. They’re not switching to your next brokerage just to keep your income stream alive.

That’s why brokerage sustainability isn’t optional – it’s everything. You need a company that won’t buckle under market pressure or tweak its revenue share model every fiscal quarter.

eXp Realty is the only public brokerage with five years of cumulative profitability. Add the #1 anonymous agent rating, and you’ve got a stable platform to build real, long-term revenue share income, not a house of cards disguised as opportunity.

Pick wrong, and your exit plan turns into damage control. Pick right, and your downline keeps paying long after you stop selling.

Recruiting Differentiation: Why It’s Not a Level Playing Field

At LPT Realty, Fathom, and Real, every agent gets the same pitch deck. That’s not hyperbole – it’s literally the same recruiting offer across the board. Your “value proposition” is whatever the brokerage already provides. So, unless you’re promising 1-on-1 hand-holding or late-night therapy sessions, it’s hard to stand out from the next recruiter down the hall.

eXp Realty, on the other hand, lets agents get creative. You offer everything eXp brings to the table,e plus build your own revenue share value stack – custom training, tech tools, marketing systems, plug-and-play templates, full-blown agent attraction funnels.

Better yet, at eXp, sponsors can team up. You can collaborate inside your downline, creating value that no single agent could pull off solo. That’s how teams like Smart Agent Alliance thrive – by stacking tools, training, and community into one irresistible recruiting engine.

Bottom line? At eXp, you’re not locked into a cookie-cutter offer. You’re free to build something agents actually want to join and stay with.

The Big Names in Revenue Sharing: Who’s In This Breakdown?

Let’s break down the real contenders in the revenue-sharing arena – the brokerages that agents most often compare when deciding where to build a downline:

  • eXp Realty – 7 tiers, 50% payout of company dollars, no fees, and no production requirement
  • LPT Realty – 7 tiers, 50% payout, dual cap options, but delays rev share for 90 days
  • Real Broker – 5 tiers, 60% payout of company dollar, but adds annual and percentage-based fees
  • Fathom Realty – 5 tiers, 50% payout, lower caps, but has production requirements and fewer unlock paths

You’ll notice we’re not fully including Keller Williams here. Why? Because KW doesn’t offer revenue share. It offers profit share, and that’s a very different animal.

Profit share vs revenue share boils down to one key thing: timing. Revenue share pays before the brokerage takes out expenses. Profit share, like KW’s, only pays out after the bills are paid at the individual market center level.

And the difference in income potential is dramatic. Example: an agent at KW with 55 people in their downline was making about $700/month in profit share. When they moved that same downline to eXp Realty, they started earning $12,000/month. Same effort, wildly different results.

So, no offense to KW agents – but in this comparison, it’s just not a fair fight. For agents serious about building long-term, scalable revenue share income, the math knocks KW out of the ring before the first bell.

Comparing Revenue Sharing Tiers: 7 Tiers vs 5 Tiers = Big Money Gap

When it comes to revenue sharing, tier count matters – a lot. The more tiers a brokerage pays on, the more income you can earn as your downline grows.

Here’s how it stacks up:

  • eXp Realty: 7 tiers
  • LPT Realty: 7 tiers
  • Real Broker: 5 tiers
  • Fathom Realty: 5 tiers

That may not seem like a big deal – until you do the math. If you sponsor 2 agents and each person brings in 2 more, a 7-tier model grows to 254 agents. A 5-tier model? Just 62. That’s over 400% more agents in your downline for the exact same effort.

Now, imagine sponsoring 30 agents who each bring in 2 more. That’s 3,810 agents in a 7-tier model vs. 930 in a 5-tier model. Spoiler alert: No 5-tier brokerage can compete with those numbers in long-term revenue share income, regardless of how they spin it.

Comparing What It Takes to Unlock Tiers

Every revenue share model makes you work a little before you unlock all those juicy downline tiers. That’s by design – nobody’s handing out seven-level payouts to someone who added their cousin and called it a day.

Here’s the deal:

All four brokerages – eXp, LPT, Real, and Fathom – require you to sponsor a certain number of producing agents to unlock deeper tiers of revenue sharing. “Producing” means they’re closing deals, not just parked in your downline.

And yes, Fathom is a little different. It lets you count any agent, producing or not, toward unlocking those tiers. That sounds nice at first, but unless those agents are selling homes, your income isn’t going anywhere.

Now here’s what most people don’t tell you: unlocking tiers isn’t instant. Your Tier 1 agents (the ones you directly sponsor) take time to bring in their own recruits. And while they’re growing their downlines, you’re still growing yours – recruiting more Tier 1s and helping them succeed.

Your downline grows outward and downward at the same time. So as more agents join, produce, and build their own teams, your overall system starts to fill out, and more tiers open up naturally.

So don’t panic if you haven’t hit Tier 7 in six months. No one starts with a full pyramid and passive checks. But if you keep at it, those unlocks start triggering – and so does the income.

Comparing What Brokerages Pay at Each Tier

Alright, let’s talk about what you actually get paid in these revenue share models – because “up to” doesn’t pay the bills.

Each brokerage has a different setup, but the concept is the same: they take what they earn from their commission split with agents, called the cap, and carve out a chunk of that to fund the available revenue share pool. That’s the pool of money used to pay agents for attracting and supporting their downlines.

Now, how much of that pool each brokerage pays out – and how it’s divided among tiers – is where things start to vary.

  • eXp Realty, LPT Realty, and Fathom Realty each commit to paying out 50% of the cap into the revenue share pool.
  • Real Broker pays 60% of its cap, but it only spreads that across 5 tiers, not 7.

Let’s break that down with a real example:

At eXp Realty, agents have a $16,000 cap. Half of that – $8,000 – goes into the available revenue share pool per agent before they cap. That $8K is then split among up to 7 tiers of agents in your upline, depending on how many tiers you’ve unlocked.

And just to complicate things, each brokerage pays different percentages at each tier. Some throw most of the money at Tier 1, while others spread it more evenly, or save the big cuts for deeper levels.

To make things even messier, some brokerages advertise the maximum possible payout, others show minimum guaranteed, and a few blur the lines between a percentage of the agent’s commission and a percentage of the available pool.

We ignored the spin and built this analysis on consistent assumptions. No cherry-picked numbers. No “maybe if” projections. Just a clear, side-by-side breakdown of what each tier pays, based on each brokerage’s real cap, tier structure, and available revenue share pool.

Extra Revenue Share: What Happens When There’s Money… But No One to Pay

Here’s a twist: a brokerage’s available revenue share pool can have more money than the minimum the brokerage agreed to pay out. Not because they’re feeling generous, but because there’s no one eligible to receive it.

Let’s say an agent closes a deal. The brokerage earns its commission split – aka the cap – and sets aside half (or more) of that into the revenue share pool. That pool is supposed to be divided among eligible sponsors across the tiers. But what if:

  • Some of those tiers haven’t been unlocked yet?
  • Some agents in the upline are inactive or didn’t meet production requirements?
  • The agent didn’t name a sponsor at all?

Now you’ve got real money with nowhere to go. What happens to that unassigned extra money depends entirely on the brokerage. eXp redistributes that extra revenue share each month to Levels 1, 2, and 3, giving newer recruiters a real income boost. It’s not small change either – many agents see 20–50% more in those early tier payouts thanks to this policy.

Important note: we didn’t factor this extra into any brokerage’s spreadsheet numbers, because it varies month to month. But if you’re comparing revenue sharing companies, ask them this: “What happens to unassigned revenue share funds?” Make sure they pass it through to recruiting agents.

Differences Too Uncertain to Calculate (But Too Important to Ignore)

Even with all the math and spreadsheets in the world, some parts of revenue sharing just can’t be cleanly calculated – because they depend on unpredictable agent behavior, hidden fine print, or fluctuating rules.

Here are the wild cards that could make or break your revenue share income, depending on the brokerage:

eXp’s Fast Start Bonus
Agents can earn up to $4,000 per recruit (instead of $1400 + extra) based on their 1st year with eXp production. It’s a serious boost, but since we can’t know how many new agents will hit the benchmark, we didn’t include it in our revenue share calculator.

LPT Realty’s 90-Day Delay
LPT doesn’t allow agents to earn revenue share income during their first 90 days. That’s a significant loss if you’re moving over a team or planning a fast start. So beware, this delay isn’t in our numbers, but it can undercut your early earnings.

Production Requirements
Some revenue-sharing companies tack on ongoing requirements.

  • Fathom: You must close 1 deal every 6 months until you’ve got 12 recruits.
  • Real: Requires agents to generate $450 in company dollars every 6 months to stay eligible.
  • LPT: Requires $15,000 in production or revenue share earnings. Predictable so our calculations include it.
  • eXp Realty: No production requirements or fees – earn from eXp revenue share whether you’re producing or not.

Real’s Revenue Share Fees
Real Broker charges $175/year plus 1.2% of all revenue share checks. These are predictable, so they’re factored into our model – but they still eat into your bottom line.

Fathom’s Unlock Advantage
Fathom lets you count non-producing agents to unlock tiers. That could speed up your revenue share model progression… but if those agents aren’t closing deals, your payout is still $0.

These factors vary so widely between agents and brokerages that they’re impossible to pin down universally. But just because some are hard to calculate doesn’t mean you should ignore them.

They’re the hidden costs and bonus opportunities that separate a great revenue share opportunity from one that quietly drains your potential.

Caution: LPT & Fathom Revenue Share Numbers May Be Inflated

Here’s a big flashing warning label before you fall in love with the spreadsheet numbers: LPT Realty and Fathom Realty offer more than one agent cap option, which makes their available revenue share pool a moving target.

To compare these brokerages with the others, we had to make assumptions about the available revenue share pool. We made generous ones.

  • LPT Realty agents can choose a $5,000 or $15,000 cap. Since 50% of that cap funds the revenue share model, it means some agents are contributing just $2,500 to the pool, others up to $7,500. We assumed a 50/50 agent split and used the midpoint: $5,000 in the pool per agent. In reality, it’s likely lower – LPT likely attracts mostly agents who choose the resulting $2500 pool.
  • Fathom Realty also has two cap options: $9,000 or $12,000, leaving either $4,500 or $6,000 in the revenue share pool. Again, we used the midpoint ($5,250) to keep comparisons fair, but real-world earnings might be significantly lower depending on what plan most agents choose.

Long story short? The numbers for LPT and Fathom in our revenue share calculator are probably on the high side. We leaned toward optimism to give them the benefit of the doubt, but if anything, actual revenue share income from these brokerages may be much lower.

So if you’re comparing revenue sharing companies and see LPT or Fathom looking competitive on paper, remember: assumptions matter. And here, the assumptions lean in their favor.

Potential Revenue Share Earnings Comparison: The Only Math That Matters

Okay, now that we’ve covered caps, tiers, unlocks, fine print, bonus policies, and fuzzy brokerage promises – let’s talk real earnings.

This is the part every agent thinks they understand… until they realize how many variables actually move the needle. It’s not just about what a brokerage pays per level or how many tiers it has. It’s about how all those pieces work together in the real world.

Our spreadsheet takes a conservative growth scenario:

  • You sponsor the stated number of agents (your Tier 1).
  • Those agents each sponsor an average of two more agents.
  • Your downline fills in tier by tier over time, naturally expanding as both you and your recruits keep building.

From there, we calculated:

  • How many agents land in each tier under each revenue share model (7-tier vs. 5-tier),
  • How much each brokerage commits to the available revenue share pool, and
  • The actual payout structure for every level.
  • With Tier 1 agents of: 2,4,5,8,10,12,16,20,30 – opening difference tiers for at least 1 brokerage.

To keep it visual (and to satisfy our inner spreadsheet nerd), we color-coded the results:

  • Dark Green = Best-earning brokerage for that agent count
  • Red = Worst-earning brokerage for that agent count
  • Light Green/Red = Second best/worst
  • Yellow = Tiers that are unlocked based on how many producing Tier 1 agents you have.

Last, to avoid bias, we show Tier 1 agent numbers below that changed the ranking order (from best to worst) of at least 1 brokerage. That avoids us choosing Tier 1 agent numbers merely to make eXp look better than others.

We were obviously thrilled to see eXp Realty outperform the competition by a wide margin – no surprise there. But we were surprised when LPT Realty edged into first place in our initial look at 20 agents. As noted above, that result hinged on a generous assumption: we calculated earnings as if half of LPT’s agents were enrolled in their higher-tier revenue share plan.

Realistically, that’s a stretch. Most agents who switch to a 100% commission brokerage like LPT (especially with their lower agent support) are doing it to maximize take-home pay, not to opt into a split with better rev share potential. So, we decided to run the numbers again, this time assuming the worst-case scenario: every agent on the lower revenue share plan.

Below we show the original calculation ($5000 for revshare pool) and the worst possibility ($2500 for revshare). We changed the highlighted color on the right to reflect how LPT Realty would then stack up against the other three brokerages. Here’s how that changed the outcome.

Bottom line: with 20 agents, LPT moves from best to 2nd best.  So, in the worst-case rev share pool scenario, LPT Realty never beats eXp Realty. Regarding the truth of LPT’s rev share pool, the truth probably falls somewhere in between these two sets of numbers. But, even then, eXp holds a strong advantage.

So, Who Actually Wins the Revenue Share Game?

Here’s the short version: not all revenue share models are worth your time. Some look good on a marketing slide but fall apart when you run the numbers – or worse, when you realize your check’s been trimmed down by mystery fees and locked tiers.

eXp Realty stands out not just because it pays well, but because it’s built to last. It offers:

  • A full 7-tier revenue sharing model
  • A massive available revenue share pool
  • No production requirements or participation fees
  • Bonus earnings from overflow payouts
  • And the only publicly traded brokerage that’s been cumulatively profitable for the past 5 years

But let’s be real, revenue share isn’t just about the brokerage. It’s also about your sponsor.

Because if you’re serious about building this income stream, who you name as your sponsor matters just as much as the model itself.

Speaking of brokerages…

When you choose Smart Agent Alliance as your sponsor at eXp Realty, you don’t just get the most profitable brokerage with the highest anonymous agent reviews. You also get the firepower of two elite sponsor teams – Smart Agent Alliance + the Wolf Pack – joining forces to actually support your business.

We’re talking:

  • A personal agent attraction page
  • Automated follow-up and webinars
  • A top-ranked team website
  • 8 lead-gen landing pages with email automation
  • 100’s of stunning plug-and-play marketing templates
  • Quick-start production plans
  • Access to everything eXp + SAA in one agent portal
  • Weekly strategy calls, high-level coaching, and private community groups
  • Social Agent Academy Pro ($10.5K value)
  • Flipping, production, systems training, and more

And yes, it’s all free when you name a Smart Agent Alliance founder as your sponsor.

So you can roll the dice with a random recruiter and hope for the best…
Or plug into a sponsor team that already built the engine – all you have to do is drive.

Curious about passive income? Try our Revenue Share Calculator.
Want to know how much more commission you’ll keep? Try our eXp Commission Calculator.

Learn more about eXp Realty.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is revenue share in real estate?

Revenue share is when a brokerage pays agents a cut of its income for referring new agents.

How does revenue share work at eXp Realty?

eXp pays up to $8,000 per agent recruited, split over 7 tiers, with no production requirement.

What’s the difference between profit share and revenue share?

Profit share pays after brokerage expenses; revenue share pays before expenses are deducted.

Which real estate brokerage has the best revenue share?

eXp Realty ranks highest due to 7 tiers, no fees, and consistent agent payouts.

Is revenue share passive income for agents?

Yes, many brokerages let agents earn rev share after retirement or even after death.

Top 4 online Missouri real estate schools

Choosing one of the best online Missouri real estate schools is vital for your career, and it’s essential to carefully research your options and understand what each course provides. While there are many real estate schools available, only a few stand out for their exceptional education and comprehensive support in helping you obtain your real estate license.

At Smart Agent Alliance, we are dedicated to helping new agents launch successful careers. That’s why we’ve put together a list of the top online real estate schools in Missouri. Our in-depth analysis covers each school’s offerings, course delivery methods, and provides a balanced view of the pros and cons of studying with each one.

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A
Top Feature: Course is easy to follow, high pass rates among students

Why We Chose It: The CE Shop offers a variety of real estate education options with an interactive and inquiry-based approach in their studying methods. While their focus is mainly on continuing education, they also provide excellent pre-licensing courses, exam prep, and post-licensing education. Their courses are accredited by ARELLO and have received numerous awards for their educational programs.

Overview: The CE Shop’s pre-licensing courses can be taken in 34 states, through four different course packages: Courses Only, Standard Package, Value Package, and Premium Package. Every package comes with business ebooks, career resources, downloadable resources, real estate glossary, digital flashcards, study schedules, and access to instructor-led webinars. Students have praised the course content for being easy to follow and highly informative, which has led to high pass rates.

Why The CE Shop is Great for Pre-Licensing: The CE Shop’s pre-licensing courses emphasize real-world applications with scenario-based learning. This approach helps students apply their knowledge to practical situations they will face in their real estate careers. Additionally, The CE Shop provides an exam prep edge program that offers additional practice tests and study aids to ensure students are well-prepared for their licensing exams.

User Experiences and Feedback: The CE Shop is well-regarded for its robust customer support and comprehensive resources. The ability to access instructor-led webinars provides an additional layer of support and interaction, which can be particularly beneficial for students who need more guidance. The frequent promotions and discounts make it a cost-effective option for many. Students appreciate the clear and structured study schedules, which help them stay on track and complete the course efficiently.

Pre-Licensing

Price Starts at: $206.50
Basic Package Features: The 72-Hour MO Sales Pre-Licensing Package, priced at $295, includes all the required 72 hours of instruction to qualify for a Missouri salesperson license. It prepares you for the Missouri state licensing exam and provides essential business knowledge for a successful real estate career in Missouri. The package comprises a 48-Hour Missouri Salesperson Pre-Examination Course and a 24-Hour Missouri Real Estate Practice Course.
Upgrade Packages: Yes, the 72-Hour MO Sales Pre-Licensing Premium Package, priced at $569, includes 84 total hours of instruction (72 core and 12 elective hours). It covers all the required hours for the Missouri salesperson license and adds extra non-credit courses to help build and grow your business. The package includes the Missouri Exam Prep Edge, an eTextbook, and your first renewal package. It also features the ProPath Real Estate Career Kickstarter program, offering courses on business planning, lead generation, and negotiation skills.

Exam Prep

Price Starts at: $101.25
Basic Package Features: The MO Salesperson Exam Prep Edge: National & State Portions, priced at $135, is an online study program that prepares you for the Missouri real estate licensing exam. It includes an initial assessment with immediate feedback, dynamic practice exams with unique questions, and real-time dashboards to track your progress. The program helps you identify areas of strength and improvement, ensuring you’re fully prepared for both the national and state portions of the exam.
Upgrade Packages: None

Continuing Education

Price Starts at: $99
Basic Package Features: The 12-Hour MO 2024-2026 CE Package, priced at $99, fulfills all 12 continuing education (CE) hours required for Missouri Broker and Sales license renewals by their respective deadlines in even-numbered years. It includes 3 core hours on Assistance Animals and Fair Housing, and 9 elective hours covering ethical dilemmas, personal safety, and technology trends. The ethics course is designed to meet the REALTOR® Code of Ethics Training Requirement, but confirmation with your local association is advised.
Upgrade Packages: Yes, the package also includes the ProPath Network Builder professional development program, which focuses on enhancing your real estate career by building a strong referral network, standing out in a competitive market, and cultivating long-term business relationships. You’ll learn essential skills in personal branding, strategic communication, market research, and conflict resolution, all aimed at boosting your visibility, client satisfaction, and overall success in the real estate industry.

Money-Back Guarantee: Full refund within 30 days if less than 50% of the course is completed.

Pass Assurance: Exam cost reimbursed if you don’t pass on the first attempt.

Exam Preparation: Targeted review sessions, custom study plans, unlimited practice tests, and live webinars.

Final Exam Procedure: Online proctoring available nationwide; California exams are administered by the DRE at specific centers.

Extra Resources: Includes digital flashcards, a real estate glossary, a study schedule, business courses, and state-specific content.

Our Review Process:

At SmartAgentAlliance, our goal is to provide accurate and helpful reviews of online real estate schools to assist prospective real estate agents in making informed decisions. Our review process involves several key steps:

Research and Data Collection:

We begin by gathering comprehensive information about each real estate school, including course offerings, pricing, accreditation, and user reviews. This involves visiting the schools’ websites, reading third-party reviews, and gathering feedback from current and former students.

Evaluation Criteria:

Our evaluation is based on several important criteria, including:

    • Course Quality:

      We assess the content and structure of the courses to ensure they cover all necessary topics comprehensively and are easy to follow.

    • Accessibility:

      We evaluate the flexibility and accessibility of the courses, including the availability of mobile apps and study materials.

    • Pass Rates:

      We consider the pass rates of students who have completed the courses and taken the licensing exam.

    • Student Support:

      We look at the level of support provided to students, including access to instructors, customer service, and additional resources like study guides and practice exams.

    • Pricing:

      We compare the cost of the courses relative to the value they offer, including any discounts or payment plans available.

    • User Feedback:

      We gather and analyze feedback from students who have taken the courses to get an understanding of their experiences and satisfaction levels.

Scoring and Ranking:

Each school is scored based on the evaluation criteria, and an overall score is calculated. The scores are then used to rank the schools, with additional considerations given to standout features that may set a school apart from the rest.

The CE Shop, Colibri Real Estate, RealEstateU, and 360 Training.

Missouri pre-license courses typically include the state-required 72 hours of education, divided into a 48-hour Salesperson Pre-Examination course and a 24-hour Missouri Real Estate Practice (MREP) course. These courses cover essential real estate principles, laws, and practices needed to pass the licensing exam. They often come with study guides, practice exams, and interactive tools to reinforce learning. Some packages also offer additional resources like exam prep courses, eTextbooks, and career coaching to help students succeed beyond the exam

To choose the best online Missouri real estate school, consider factors like course content, student support, flexibility, and pricing. Look for schools with high pass rates, comprehensive study materials, and interactive tools to enhance learning. Ensure the school is approved by the Missouri Real Estate Commission and offers flexible study options like self-paced or live-stream classes. Additionally, compare costs, including any available discounts or payment plans, and check for student reviews to gauge satisfaction and course effectiveness?.

Yes, most online real estate courses are self-paced, allowing you to study at your own convenience. This flexibility is ideal for students who need to balance their studies with work or other commitments.

Support varies by school but generally includes access to instructors via email or chat, customer service support, and sometimes live webinars or Q&A sessions.

The cost of online real estate courses varies by school and package. Basic pre-license courses can start around $100, while comprehensive packages with additional features like exam prep and career support can cost several hundred dollars.

content:
How to Get Your Missouri Real Estate License

Embarking on your real estate career in Missouri may feel overwhelming at first, but with the right steps, it becomes a clear and attainable goal. This thorough guide is designed to take you through each vital phase, ensuring you’re well-prepared to start your journey as a licensed real estate agent in the Show-Me State. Let’s dive into the process that will set you on the path to success in Missouri’s real estate market.

Before we dive into the detailed process, it’s important to grasp the fundamental requirements for earning a real estate license in Indiana. Here’s what you need to know:

To qualify for a real estate license in Missouri, you must be at least 18 years old. This ensures that applicants possess the necessary maturity and legal accountability for a career in real estate.

Missouri does not require you to be a resident to apply for a real estate license. However, you must have a valid Social Security number, which is essential for conducting background checks and ensuring compliance with state regulations. Non-residents are subject to the same standards as Missouri residents.

Ethical behavior is paramount in the real estate industry. The Missouri Real Estate Commission requires all applicants to undergo a thorough criminal history background check, including fingerprinting. Any criminal record could result in the denial of your application, but being upfront about any past issues and demonstrating rehabilitation can improve your chances of approval?.

In Missouri, aspiring real estate agents must complete 72 hours of pre-licensing education. This course is structured to provide comprehensive coverage of essential topics, thoroughly preparing you for the licensing exam and your future career in real estate.

The Missouri pre-licensing course includes detailed instruction on critical areas of real estate. The curriculum focuses on state-specific laws, real estate finance, agency principles, and property transactions, ensuring you have the necessary knowledge to succeed in the field.

This core module introduces you to the fundamental principles and practices of real estate. You’ll explore topics such as property rights, land use, contracts, and the role of a real estate agent, all tailored to Missouri’s unique market requirements. This foundational knowledge equips you with the skills needed to thrive in Missouri’s real estate landscape?.

This segment focuses on Missouri-specific real estate laws, covering topics like civil rights, housing discrimination, and key federal legislation, including the Fair Housing Act and Equal Credit Opportunity Act. You’ll gain a deep understanding of how these laws apply within Missouri, preparing you to navigate both state and federal regulations effectively.

Selecting the right real estate school is crucial. Look for accredited schools that offer flexibility, especially if you have a busy schedule. Online courses can provide the convenience of studying at your own pace.

Start by researching various real estate schools and reading reviews from past students. Look for schools with high pass rates for the real estate exam and positive feedback on their teaching methods.

Decide whether you prefer online or in-person classes. Online courses offer flexibility and convenience, allowing you to study at your own pace. In-person classes provide direct interaction with instructors and peers, which can enhance your learning experience.

Evaluate the course materials and support services provided by the school. High-quality textbooks, interactive lessons, and access to instructors for questions can significantly impact your success. Some schools also offer additional resources like exam prep courses and study groups.

Create a daily study schedule that covers all exam topics, ensuring regular review sessions. (Asana provides a great FREE task manager)

Utilize flashcards for key terms and concepts to enhance memorization. (These Quizlet Flashcards may be helpful)

Regularly take practice tests to gauge your understanding and get familiar with the exam format. (Free Missouri Real Estate Practice Exam)

After completing your pre-licensing education, the next essential step is submitting your license application to the Missouri Real Estate Commission (MREC).

Complete the Application Form: Visit the Missouri Real Estate Commission (MREC) website to access and fill out the application form. Make sure all information is accurate and complete.

Gather Required Documents: Prepare all necessary documentation, including your Certificate of Completion for the pre-licensing courses, proof of identification, and any additional forms required by the MREC.

Submit Your Application: Submit your completed application and all required documents via mail to the Missouri Real Estate Commission. Ensure that everything is in order before mailing to avoid delays.

Pay the Application Fee: Pay the required application fee, which is typically $90. This fee can be paid by check or money order, and must be included with your mailed application.

The Missouri Real Estate Commission will typically take a few weeks to process your application. During this period, they will verify your educational credentials and ensure all requirements have been satisfied. To prevent delays, double-check your application and documents before submission. 

While Missouri doesn’t offer an online tracking system like some states, you can contact the MREC directly to inquire about your application status if needed. Staying proactive in checking your status can help you quickly resolve any issues that might arise.

The Missouri Real Estate Exam is a comprehensive test that evaluates your knowledge of both general real estate principles and Missouri-specific laws. The exam consists of two portions—national and state—with a total of 140 multiple-choice questions. To pass, you need a score of at least 70% on the national portion and 75% on the state portion. If you do not pass on your first attempt, you will need to reschedule and pay the exam fee of $62 for each attempt?.

Agency Relationships and Contracts: Covers the principles and practices related to agency agreements, fiduciary responsibilities, and contract law in real estate transactions.

Marketing Regulations (purchase and rental): Focuses on the legal aspects of marketing real estate, including compliance with advertising laws and regulations governing the sale and rental of properties.

Property Management: Deals with the management of rental properties, including leases, landlord-tenant relationships, and the handling of property maintenance and finances.

Real Property Ownership/Interest: Discusses the various types of property ownership, rights, and interests, including freehold and leasehold estates.

Finance: Covers the financial aspects of real estate transactions, such as mortgages, loan types, interest rates, and financing methods.

Real Property: Encompasses the physical and legal characteristics of land and buildings, zoning laws, and property use regulations.

Real Estate Calculations: Focuses on the mathematical calculations involved in real estate, such as determining property values, mortgage payments, and commission structures.

The Real Estate Commission: Oversees the licensing and conduct of real estate professionals in Missouri, ensuring compliance with state laws and ethical standards.

Licensure: The process of obtaining and renewing a real estate license in Missouri, including education, examination, and background checks managed by the Missouri Real Estate Commission.

Regulations of Licensee Conduct: Legal and ethical standards that Missouri real estate professionals must follow, including proper advertising, client fund management, and disclosure obligations.

Regulation of Agency Conduct: Rules governing how real estate agencies operate in Missouri, focusing on ethical transactions, client responsibilities, and compliance with MREC regulations.

Go over the textbooks and notes from your pre-license courses. Revisiting these materials can reinforce your understanding of key concepts. Focus on areas where you feel less confident to ensure a well-rounded preparation.

Take as many practice exams as possible. This helps you get familiar with the exam format and identify areas where you need more study. Practice exams can also help you manage your time effectively during the actual test. (Free Ohio Real Estate Practice Exam)

Join or form study groups. Discussing topics with peers can enhance understanding and retention. Study groups provide a platform to share knowledge, ask questions, and support each other.

Consider enrolling in an exam prep course for additional support and structured study. These courses often include practice exams, study guides, and expert instruction. Investing in a prep course can increase your chances of passing the exam on the first attempt.

Ensure you arrive at the exam center early to avoid any last-minute stress. Arriving early gives you time to settle in and focus before the exam begins. Check the location and travel time in advance to plan your journey.

You’ll need a valid photo ID to enter the exam. Make sure your ID is current and matches the name on your application. Having all necessary documents ready can prevent any issues at the exam center.

Read each question carefully and manage your time wisely. Staying calm and composed can help you think clearly and avoid mistakes. Take deep breaths and stay positive throughout the exam.

Follow all instructions given by the exam proctors. Adhering to the rules ensures a smooth and fair testing experience for everyone. If you have any questions or issues, ask the proctors for assistance.

After passing the Missouri real estate exam, the next step is to complete the fingerprinting requirement as part of the mandatory criminal background check. This step ensures you meet the integrity and honesty standards set by the Missouri Real Estate Commission (MREC).

Do not schedule your fingerprinting until you have completed the pre-licensing education and passed the state exam. Ensure all necessary documents are in order before proceeding with fingerprinting.

Once ready, schedule your fingerprinting appointment through IdentoGO, the approved provider for Missouri. You can do this online by selecting Missouri and choosing “Digital Fingerprinting.” During registration, you will need to enter the service code provided by the MREC.

On the day of your appointment, bring a valid form of identification, such as a driver’s license, state ID, or passport. The fingerprinting process will electronically capture your fingerprints and submit them to the Missouri State Highway Patrol and FBI for processing.

The cost for fingerprinting in Missouri is approximately $40.50, which is paid during the scheduling process.

The MREC will conduct a background check using your fingerprints to verify that you meet the required ethical standards. If any concerns are identified during this check, you may need to provide additional documentation or resolve issues before your license can be issued?

If any issues arise during the background check, you may need to provide additional documentation or explanations. Being upfront about past incidents and providing thorough documentation can positively influence the outcome. If you have concerns, consider consulting with legal counsel to navigate the process.

After completing your exam and fingerprinting requirements, the final step is to submit your Salesperson License Application to the Missouri Real Estate Commission (MREC) to confirm your eligibility.

Fill out the Salesperson License Application form available on the Missouri Real Estate Commission’s website. Ensure that all sections are accurately completed. The form can be accessed and submitted online or mailed to the MREC office.

Include proof that you passed the Missouri real estate exam. This documentation is necessary for the MREC to verify your eligibility. Keep a copy of your exam results for your records?.

Attach your IdentoGO fingerprinting receipt as proof that you have completed the fingerprinting requirement. Make sure all necessary signatures and information are correctly provided.

As of 2024, the fee for the Salesperson License in Missouri is $90. This fee must be submitted along with your application. Keep a copy of your payment receipt for future reference.

After submitting your application, you can track its status through the Missouri Real Estate Commission (MREC) website. Regularly checking the status will help you stay informed about the progress of your application and any additional requirements that may arise. If there are delays or issues, contacting the MREC directly can provide clarity and help move the process along more smoothly.

Once you pass the exam, you need to find a sponsoring broker to activate your license. Look for a brokerage that aligns with your goals and offers the support you need.

Find a supportive and collaborative environment. The right culture can significantly impact your job satisfaction and success.

Understand the financial arrangements. Different brokerages offer different commission splits, so choose one that suits your financial goals.

Choose a broker who provides ample training and mentorship opportunities. Early career support is crucial for your development and success.

17 Brokerage Interview Questions

  • What training programs do you offer for new agents?
  • How does your commission split work, and are there any additional fees?
  • What kind of support and resources will I have access to?
  • Can you provide references from other agents in your brokerage?

Choosing the right broker is crucial as it impacts your early career significantly. Consider top-rated brokers like eXp Realty, Keller Williams, Coldwell Banker, and Compass.

When you join Smart Agent Alliance, you get double the value because you’re also automatically a Wolf Pack member.  Together, Smart Agent Alliance and the Wolf Pack provide the tools, support, and expertise to elevate your business to new heights.

At Smart Agent Alliance, we prioritize organization, clarity, and efficiency to help our agents succeed. We provide essential onboarding resources, customizable presentations, business automations, client checklists, business assets, social media content, YouTube support, a growth plan, quality lead generation, production know-how, website support, and top-notch organizational tools.

The Wolf Pack team at eXp Realty offers expert-led courses like Social Agent Academy 3.0, the Wolf Pack Hub, and the Investor Army for property flipping. We provide tailored assistance for new agents, developing agents, top producers, team leaders, and broker owners. Key resources include lead generation, production know-how, social media content, and YouTube support.

eXp Realty offers a comprehensive range of benefits for agents, focusing on top pay structures, low fees, and free stock options. Agents get an 80/20 commission splits that cap at $16,000 annually, with opportunities to earn 100% commission, receive annual stock awards and gain income through Revenue Share. Additional resources include 24/7 agent support, affordable healthcare, live training, and advanced tech tools like kvCORE and customizable IDX websites.

Embarking on a real estate career involves some initial expenses and careful financial planning. Understanding these costs will help you manage your finances effectively as you begin your new career.

All stated fees are subject to change.

 

  • When getting started in real estate, there are various initial costs to consider, including licensing, marketing, and business setup. Some examples of initial expenses in Missouri include:
    • Pre-Licensing Course: $199 – $500
    • Exam Fee: $62 per attempt
    • Application Fee: $90
    • Fingerprinting Fee: Approximately $40.50
    • Marketing Materials: Costs for business cards, signage, and online advertising

When you join a brokerage in Missouri, many will require you to become a member of the National, State, and Local Associations of Realtors. Additionally, you’ll need to pay fees for the Multiple Listing Service (MLS) and Supra Key services.

National Association of Realtors (NAR)

  • Membership Fees: For 2024, the NAR annual dues are $156, plus a $45 special assessment fee for the Consumer Advertising Campaign, bringing the total to $201 per year.

Missouri Realtors (State Association)

  • Membership Fees: The annual dues for Missouri Realtors in 2024 are approximately $150. This fee is in addition to the NAR dues.

Local Association of Realtors

  • Membership Fees: Local association fees in Missouri vary depending on the specific association. For example:
    • St. Louis Realtors: The annual dues are approximately $600, plus a one-time application fee.
    • Kansas City Regional Association of Realtors: Fees are generally around $525 annually, with additional costs for new members.

Multiple Listing Service (MLS)

  • Fees: MLS fees in Missouri also vary by region. For example:
    • MARIS MLS (St. Louis area): Fees are approximately $528 annually.
    • Heartland MLS (Kansas City area): The fees typically range from $150 to $200 quarterly.

Supra Key Fees

  • Fees: Supra Key services in Missouri typically include an initial setup fee of about $50 and a monthly service fee ranging from $18 to $25, depending on the region and service package.
  • Create a Budget: Track your expenses and forecast your income. Plan for slower months to ensure financial stability.
  • Emergency Fund: Set aside an emergency fund to cover unexpected expenses or slow periods in the market
  • Commission Structure: Real estate agents typically earn commissions from sales. Understand how your brokerage’s commission structure works and how to manage irregular income streams. Commission splits can vary widely, typically ranging from 50/50 to 70/30 or higher, depending on the brokerage.
  • Tax Planning: As an independent contractor, it’s important to plan for taxes. Keep track of deductible expenses, make estimated tax payments, and maintain good record-keeping practices. Consulting with a tax professional can help ensure compliance and optimize your tax strategy.

To obtain a Missouri real estate license, you must meet the following requirements:

  1. Age: Be at least 18 years old.
  2. Education: Complete 72 hours of pre-licensing education, which includes a 48-hour Salesperson Pre-Examination course and a 24-hour Missouri Real Estate Practice (MREP) course.
  3. Examination: Pass the Missouri Real Estate Salesperson Exam, which consists of both national and state-specific portions.
  4. Background Check: Complete a fingerprinting process and pass a criminal background check through the Missouri State Highway Patrol and the FBI.
  5. Application: Submit your license application to the Missouri Real Estate Commission (MREC) within six months of completing your pre-licensing education, along with the required application fee.

These steps ensure that you are qualified and prepared to start your career as a real estate agent in Missouri.

The cost to get a real estate license in Missouri includes several key expenses:

  1. Pre-Licensing Education: $199 to $500, depending on the course provider.
  2. Exam Fee: $62 per attempt.
  3. Application Fee: $90 for the Salesperson License.
  4. Fingerprinting Fee: Approximately $40.50.
  5. Additional Costs: Marketing materials, association memberships, and MLS fees can add to the total expenses.

Overall, you can expect to spend around $400 to $700 to get your real estate license in Missouri.

The time it takes to get a real estate license in Missouri varies but generally includes:

  1. Pre-Licensing Education: Completing the required 72 hours of coursework can take between 2 to 6 weeks, depending on whether you study full-time or part-time.
  2. Exam Preparation and Scheduling: Preparing for and scheduling the Missouri Real Estate Salesperson Exam can take another 1 to 2 weeks.
  3. Fingerprinting and Background Check: This process typically takes about 1 to 2 weeks.
  4. Application Processing: Once submitted, the Missouri Real Estate Commission (MREC) usually processes your application within 1 to 2 weeks.

In total, it typically takes around 2 to 3 months to get your real estate license in Missouri, depending on your pace and the processing times.

The pass rate for the Missouri real estate exam typically ranges between 60% and 70%. This means that out of all the candidates who take the exam, around 60% to 70% successfully pass on their first attempt. The exam includes both national and state-specific sections, and you must pass both to obtain your license.

It’s important to thoroughly prepare for the exam by completing your pre-licensing education and utilizing exam prep resources to improve your chances of success?.

If you fail the Missouri real estate exam, you can retake the test. You’ll need to pay the exam fee of $62 for each attempt. It’s important to focus on the sections you found challenging, as the exam covers both national and state-specific content. You can retake the exam as many times as needed, but you must pass both portions to qualify for your license. Consider using additional study resources or taking practice exams to improve your chances of passing on your next attempt?.

To renew your Missouri real estate license, follow these steps:

  1. Complete Continuing Education: You must complete 12 hours of continuing education (CE) every two years, including at least 3 hours focused on core topics like fair housing.
  2. Log in to the MREC Online Portal: Use your PIN and license number to access the Missouri Real Estate Commission (MREC) online renewal system.
  3. Verify Information: Check and update your personal and contact information as needed.
  4. Pay the Renewal Fee: The renewal fee is typically $65. Be sure to submit payment before the expiration date to avoid late fees.
  5. Submit the Renewal Application: Once all steps are complete, submit your renewal application online.

Timely completion of these steps will ensure your license remains active?.

All stated fees are subject to change.

 

  • Initial Expenses: These include various costs associated with getting licensed, marketing, and setting up your business. Some examples of initial expenses in Indiana include:
    • Pre-Licensing Course: $290 to $750
    • Exam Fee: $53 per attempt
    • Application Fee: $60
    • Fingerprinting Fee: Approximately $38.20
    • Marketing Materials: Costs for business cards, signage, and online advertising

When you join a brokerage in Indiana, many will require you to become a member of the National, State, and Local Associations of Realtors. Additionally, you’ll need to pay fees for the Multiple Listing Service (MLS) and Supra Key services.

National Association of Realtors (NAR):

  • Membership Fees: For 2024, the NAR annual dues are $156, plus a $45 special assessment fee for the Consumer Advertising Campaign, bringing the total to $201 per year.

Indiana Realtors (State Association):

  • Membership Fees: The annual dues for Indiana Realtors in 2024 are approximately $150. This fee is in addition to the NAR dues.

Local Association of Realtors:

  • Membership Fees: Local association fees in Indiana vary depending on the specific association. For example:
    • MIBOR Realtor Association (Indianapolis area): The annual dues are approximately $1,070, plus a $400 application fee.
    • Upstate Alliance of Realtors (Fort Wayne area): The fees are generally around $934, plus a $150 join fee.

Multiple Listing Service (MLS):

  • Fees: MLS fees in Indiana also vary by region. For example:
    • MIBOR MLS: Fees are approximately $480 annually.
    • IRMLS (Indiana Regional MLS): The fees typically range from $150 to $175 quarterly.

Supra Key Fees:

  • Fees: Supra Key services in Indiana typically include an initial setup fee of about $50 and a monthly service fee ranging from $20 to $25.
  • Create a Budget: Track your expenses and forecast your income. Plan for slower months to ensure financial stability.
  • Emergency Fund: Set aside an emergency fund to cover unexpected expenses or slow periods in the market
  • Commission Structure: Real estate agents typically earn commissions from sales. Understand how your brokerage’s commission structure works and how to manage irregular income streams. Commission splits can vary widely, typically ranging from 50/50 to 70/30 or higher, depending on the brokerage.
  • Tax Planning: As an independent contractor, it’s important to plan for taxes. Keep track of deductible expenses, make estimated tax payments, and maintain good record-keeping practices. Consulting with a tax professional can help ensure compliance and optimize your tax strategy.

To obtain a real estate license in Indiana, you must meet the following requirements:

  1. Age Requirement: You must be at least 18 years old.
  2. Education Requirement: Complete 90 hours of pre-licensing education from an accredited provider.
  3. Pass the State Exam: You must pass the Indiana Real Estate Exam, which includes both national and state-specific portions.
  4. Complete a Background Check: Submit fingerprints and pass a criminal background check as part of the licensing process.
  5. Submit an Application: Apply for your license through the Indiana Professional Licensing Agency (IPLA), including payment of the $60 application fee.
  6. Affiliate with a Brokerage: You must be associated with an active Indiana brokerage to receive your license and start practicing.

These steps ensure you are fully qualified to start your career as a real estate professional in Indiana?

The cost to get a real estate license in Indiana varies, but here’s a breakdown:

  1. Pre-Licensing Course: $290 to $750
  2. Exam Fee: $53 per attempt
  3. Application Fee: $60
  4. Fingerprinting/Background Check: Approximately $38.20
  5. Optional Exam Prep Materials: $35 to $170

Total Estimated Cost: $450 to $1,040, depending on course selection and additional resources.

The time it takes to get a real estate license in Indiana typically ranges from 3 to 4 months. This includes:

  1. Pre-Licensing Education: Completing the required 90 hours of coursework, which can take anywhere from 2.5 weeks to several months, depending on your pace.
  2. Exam Preparation and Scheduling: Preparing for and scheduling the exam, which may take additional time.
  3. Application Processing: Once you pass the exam and submit your application, it usually takes 2 to 5 business days for the Indiana Professional Licensing Agency (IPLA) to process your license?.

The Indiana real estate exam pass rate is not officially published by the state. However, it is generally considered challenging, with many candidates needing multiple attempts to pass. The exam requires a score of at least 75%, which means you need to answer at least 60 out of 75 national questions and 38 out of 50 state-specific questions correctly to pass?.

Since specific pass rate statistics are not released, it’s important to thoroughly prepare using exam prep courses and practice tests.

If you fail the Indiana real estate exam, you can retake it as many times as necessary within one year of completing your pre-licensing education. You only need to retake the portion of the exam (national or state-specific) that you didn’t pass. Each attempt costs $53. It’s advisable to review your weak areas and consider using additional study materials or prep courses to improve your chances of passing on subsequent attempts.

To renew your Indiana real estate license, follow these steps:

1. Complete Continuing Education: You must complete 12 hours of continuing education (CE) annually, totaling 36 hours over the three-year renewal period. Courses must be approved by the Indiana Real Estate Commission.

2. Submit Renewal Application: Once your CE requirements are met, submit your renewal application online through the Indiana Professional Licensing Agency (IPLA) portal.

3. Pay the Renewal Fee: The renewal fee is $60, payable online during the application submission.

4. Check Deadlines: Licenses must be renewed every three years. Ensure you complete all requirements and submit your application before the expiration date to avoid penalties?
